div1.head: CHARACTERS

list.item: HIALMAR EKDAL, his son, a photographer.
HEDVIG, their daughter, a girl of fourteen.
SIX OTHER GENTLEMEN, guests at Werle's dinner-party.

div1.p: The first act passes in WERLE'S house, the remaining acts at HJALMAR EKDAL'S.
Pronunciation of Names: GREGERS WERLE = Grayghers Verle; HIALMAR EKDAL = Yalmar Aykdal; GINA = Cheena; GRABERG = Groberg; JENSEN = Yensen.

sp.speaker: Relling.
sp.p: Well, you see, I'm supposed to be a sort of a doctor — save the mark! I can't but give a hand to the poor sick folk who live under the same roof with me.

sp.speaker: Gregers.
sp.p: Oh, indeed! Hialmar Ekdal is sick too, is he!

sp.speaker: Relling.
sp.p: Most people are, worse luck.

sp.speaker: Gregers.
sp.p: And what remedy are you applying in Hialmar's case?

sp.speaker: Relling.
sp.p: My usual one. I am cultivating the life-illusion* in him.

sp.speaker: Gregers.
sp.p: Life-illusion? I didn't catch what you said.

sp.speaker: Relling.
sp.p: Yes, I said illusion. For illusion, you know, is the stimulating principle.

sp.speaker: Gregers.
sp.p: May I ask with what illusion Hialmar is inoculated?

sp.speaker: Relling.
sp.p: No, thank you; I don't betray professional secrets to quacksalvers. You would probably go and muddle his case still more than you have already. But my method is infallible. I have applied it to Molvik as well. I have made him "daemonic." That's the blister I have to put on his neck.

sp.speaker: Gregers.
sp.p: Is he not really daemonic then?

sp.speaker: Relling.
sp.p: What the devil do you mean by daemonic! It's only a piece of gibberish I've invented to keep up a spark of life in him. But for that, the poor harmless creature would have succumbed to self-contempt and despair many a long year ago. And then the old lieutenant! But he has hit upon his own cure, you see.

sp.speaker: Gregers.
sp.p: Lieutenant Ekdal? What of him?

sp.speaker: Relling.
sp.p:
Just think of the old bear-hunter shutting himself up in that dark garret to shoot rabbits! I tell you there is not a happier sportsman in the world than that old man pottering about in there among all that rubbish. The four or five withered Christmas-trees he has saved up are the same to him as the whole great fresh Hoidal forest; the cock and the hens are big game-birds in the fir-tops; and the rabbits that flop about the garret floor are the bears * "Livslognen,"
literally "the life-lie."
he has to battle with — the mighty hunter of the mountains!

sp.speaker: Gregers.
sp.p: Poor unfortunate old man! Yes; he has indeed had to narrow the ideals of his youth.

sp.speaker: Relling.
sp.p: While I think of it, Mr. Werle, junior — don't use that foreign word: ideals. We have the excellent native word: lies.

sp.speaker: Gregers.
sp.p: Do you think the two things are related?

sp.speaker: Relling.
sp.p: Yes, just about as closely as typhus and putrid fever.

sp.speaker: Gregers.
sp.p: Dr. Relling, I shall not give up the struggle until I have rescued Hialmar from your clutches!

sp.speaker: Relling.
sp.p: So much the worse for him. Rob the average man of his life-illusion, and you rob him of his happiness at the same stroke. (To HEDVIG, who comes in from the sitting-room.) Well, little wild-duck-mother, I'm just going down to see whether papa is still lying meditating upon that wonderful invention of his.

sp.speaker: Gregers
sp.p: I can see by your face that you have not yet done it.

sp.speaker: Hedvig.
sp.p: What? Oh, that about the wild duck! No.

sp.speaker: Gregers.
sp.p: I suppose your courage failed when the time came.

sp.speaker: Hedvig.
sp.p: No, that wasn't it. But when I awoke this morning and remembered what we had been talking about, it seemed so strange.

sp.speaker: Gregers.
sp.p: Strange?

sp.speaker: Hedvig.
sp.p: Yes, I don't know — Yesterday evening, at the moment, I thought there was something so delightful about it; but since I have slept and thought of it again, it somehow doesn't seem worth while.

sp.speaker: Gregers.
sp.p: Ah, I thought you could not have grown up quite unharmed in this house.

sp.speaker: Hedvig.
sp.p: I don't care about that, if only father would come up —

sp.speaker: Gregers.
sp.p:
Oh, if only your eyes had been opened to that
which gives life its value — if you possessed the true, joyous, fearless spirit of sacrifice, you would soon see how he would come up to you. — But I believe in you still, Hedvig.

stage.p: [He goes out by the passage door. HEDVIG wanders about the room for a time; she is on the point of going into the kitchen when a knock is heard at the garret door. HEDVIG goes over and opens it a little; old EKDAL comes out; she pushes the door to again.

sp.speaker: Ekdal.
sp.p: H'm, it's not much fun to take one's morning walk alone.

sp.speaker: Hedvig.
sp.p: Wouldn't you like to go shooting, grandfather?

sp.speaker: Ekdal.
sp.p: It's not the weather for it to-day. It's so dark there, you can scarcely see where you're going.

sp.speaker: Hedvig.
sp.p: Do you never want to shoot anything besides the rabbits?

sp.speaker: Ekdal.
sp.p: Do you think the rabbits aren't good enough?

sp.speaker: Hedvig.
sp.p: Yes, but what about the wild duck?

sp.speaker: Ekdal.
sp.p: Ho-ho! are you afraid I shall shoot your wild duck? Never in the world. Never.

sp.speaker: Hedvig.
sp.p: No, I suppose you couldn't; they say it's very difficult to shoot wild ducks.

sp.speaker: Ekdal.
sp.p: Couldn't! Should rather think I could.

sp.speaker: Hedvig.
sp.p: How would you set about it, grandfather? — I don't mean with my wild duck, but with others?

sp.speaker: Ekdal.
sp.p: I should take care to shoot them in the breast, you know; that's the surest place. And then you must shoot against the feathers, you see — not the way of the feathers.

sp.speaker: Hedvig.
sp.p: Do they die then, grandfather?

sp.speaker: Ekdal.
sp.p: Yes, they die right enough — when you shoot properly. — Well, I must go and brush up a bit. H'm — understand — h'm.

stage.p:
[HEDVIG waits a little, glances towards the sitting-room door, goes over to the book-case, stands on tip-toe, takes the double-barrelled pistol down
from the shelf, and looks at it. GINA, with brush and duster, comes from the sitting-room. HEDVIG hastily lays down the pistol, unobserved.
